docs.title: My Notes
docs.text: This site contains personal notes for setting up development tools, documentation sites, and local AI servers.

docs.title: Guide Directory
docs.text:
• Developer Tools: Setting up Zoxide, Zed, and Mac Terminal shortcuts.
  • Notes Site Setup: Building and publishing this documentation site.
  • LiteLLM Server: Running an OpenAI-compatible proxy for local and cloud AI models.
  • LightRAG Server: Running a personal RAG search server as a native Mac app.

docs.title: 1. Setup ⌘ + G Shortcut
docs.text: This guide configures a custom keyboard shortcut (⌘ + G) on macOS to instantly open the Terminal in whatever folder you have selected in Finder.

docs.title: Enable the Service
docs.text:
1. Open macOS System Settings.
  2. Go to Keyboard on the left menu.
  3. Click the Keyboard Shortcuts... button on the right.
  4. Select Services on the left menu.
  5. Expand the Files and Folders section.
  6. Check the box next to New Terminal at Folder.

docs.title: Set the Shortcut
docs.text:
1. In that same window, double-click the word "none" (or the existing shortcut) on the right side of the New Terminal at Folder row.
  2. Press ⌘ + G on your keyboard to record the new shortcut.
  3. Click Done.

Now, when you select any folder in Finder, you can press ⌘ + G to instantly open a Terminal window at that exact location.

docs.title: 1. Installation
docs.text: Zed is a fast, Rust-based code editor that supports Language Server Protocol (LSP) for real-time error checking.

docs.title: Install Zed
docs.text:
1. Open Terminal (⌘ + Space, type "Terminal", press Enter).
  2. Run this command: 
    brew install --cask zed

docs.title: Make Zed the Default Editor
docs.text:
We want Zed to automatically open when double-clicking Markdown (.md) notes or configuration (.yml, .env) files in Finder.

  1. Open Terminal.
  2. Run these commands to configure macOS file associations: 
    duti -s dev.zed.Zed .md all
duti -s dev.zed.Zed .yml all
duti -s dev.zed.Zed .yaml all
duti -s dev.zed.Zed .env all
duti -s dev.zed.Zed .txt all

Now, any .md, .yml, .yaml, .env, or .txt file you double-click in Finder will instantly open in Zed.

Next: You can now proceed to Setup Notes Site.

docs.title: 1. What is Zoxide?
docs.text:
Zoxide is a faster replacement for cd in the Terminal. It remembers the folders you visit most often so you can jump straight to them using just z <foldername>.

Next: 2. Installation

docs.title: 1. Install with Homebrew
docs.text:
Open Terminal and run:

brew install zoxide

docs.title: 2. Hook into ZSH
docs.text:
Zoxide needs to launch every time you open a Terminal. We add it to your ~/.zshrc file.

  1. Open Finder and go to your home folder (⇧ + ⌘ + H).
  2. Press ⇧ + ⌘ + . to show hidden files.
  3. Find the .zshrc file and open it in Zed. (If it doesn't exist, create a new blank text document and name it .zshrc).
  4. Paste this line at the very bottom of the file: 
    # Initialize Zoxide for fast folder navigation
eval "$(zoxide init zsh)"
  5. Save the file and close Zed.
  6. Restart your Terminal for the changes to take effect.

Next: 3. Basic Usage

docs.title: 3. Basic Usage
docs.text: Use cd normally a few times to visit your project folders so Zoxide can "learn" them. After that, you can use z.

docs.title: Jump to a Folder
docs.text:
Instead of cd, just type z and part of the folder name:

z rag
(This instantly jumps to your /Users/myuser/RAGprojects/rag-notes folder).

docs.title: Interactive Search
docs.text:
If you forgot the exact name or want to see a list of matches:

  1. Type z <keyword> and press the Tab key ⇥ (e.g., z proj<Tab>).
  2. Use the arrow keys ↓ ↑ to select the right folder.
  3. Press Enter.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text: LightRAG runs a personal AI search server on your Mac. These notes cover how to install it, configure it with an AI model, and wrap it into a double-clickable Mac app using a tool called Platypus.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
1. AI Provider: You need an API key (OpenAI, Google Gemini) or a local provider installed (Ollama).
  2. Platypus: Download Platypus. Open the .zip and drag Platypus.app into your Applications folder using Finder.

Next: 2. Installation

docs.title: 2. Installation
docs.text:
Install the lightrag-server command-line tool. Open Terminal and run:

uv tool install "lightrag-hku[offline,observability]"

To confirm it installed correctly, run:

which lightrag-server

You should see a path like ~/.local/bin/lightrag-server.

Next: 3. Configuration

docs.title: 1. Create Folders
docs.text:
1. Open Finder and go to your home folder (⇧ + ⌘ + H).
  2. Create a folder named LightRAG.
  3. Open LightRAG and create a folder inside it named inputs.

docs.title: 2. Create the Configuration File
docs.text:
1. Open Zed and create a new blank document (⌘ + N).
  2. Paste the configuration block below into it (choose your provider section).
  3. Save the file directly into the LightRAG folder. Note: You must name the file EXACTLY .env (it will warn you that starting with a dot makes it hidden — click "Use .").

If the .env file disappears after saving, press ⇧ + ⌘ + . inside Finder to show hidden files.

docs.title: The Config Template
docs.text:
# --- General Server Settings ---
HOST=127.0.0.1
PORT=8020
WEBUI_TITLE=My Personal RAG
WEBUI_DESCRIPTION=A private RAG system powered by LightRAG

# --- Directory Settings ---
WORKING_DIR=/Users/YOUR_MAC_USERNAME/LightRAG
INPUT_DIR=/Users/YOUR_MAC_USERNAME/LightRAG/inputs

# --- Indexing Performance ---
MAX_ASYNC=4
MAX_PARALLEL_INSERT=2
CHUNK_SIZE=1200
CHUNK_OVERLAP_SIZE=100

# ==========================================
# CHOOSE ONE PROVIDER BELOW AND UNCOMMENT IT
# ==========================================

# --- Option 1: OLLAMA ---
# LLM_BINDING=ollama
# LLM_BINDING_HOST=http://localhost:11434
# LLM_MODEL=mistral-nemo:latest
# OLLAMA_LLM_NUM_CTX=32768
# EMBEDDING_BINDING=ollama
# EMBEDDING_BINDING_HOST=http://localhost:11434
# EMBEDDING_MODEL=bge-m3:latest
# EMBEDDING_DIM=1024

# --- Option 2: OPENAI ---
# LLM_BINDING=openai
# LLM_BINDING_HOST=https://api.openai.com/v1
# LLM_MODEL=gpt-4o
# LLM_BINDING_API_KEY=sk-your-api-key-here
# EMBEDDING_BINDING=openai
# EMBEDDING_BINDING_HOST=https://api.openai.com/v1
# EMBEDDING_MODEL=text-embedding-3-large
# EMBEDDING_BINDING_API_KEY=sk-your-api-key-here

# --- Option 3: GEMINI ---
# LLM_BINDING=gemini
# LLM_MODEL=gemini-2.5-flash
# LLM_BINDING_HOST=https://generativelanguage.googleapis.com
# LLM_BINDING_API_KEY=your-gemini-api-key-here
# EMBEDDING_BINDING=gemini
# EMBEDDING_MODEL=gemini-embedding-001
# EMBEDDING_BINDING_HOST=https://generativelanguage.googleapis.com
# EMBEDDING_BINDING_API_KEY=your-gemini-api-key-here
# EMBEDDING_DIM=1536

docs.title: 3. Create the Launcher Script
docs.text:
Platypus needs a simple script to launch the server.

  1. Open Zed and create a new blank document (⌘ + N).
  2. Paste this exact code:
#!/bin/zsh
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"
WORKING_DIR="$HOME/LightRAG"
mkdir -p "$WORKING_DIR"
cd "$WORKING_DIR"
exec lightrag-server --working-dir "$WORKING_DIR"
  1. Save it into your LightRAG folder and name it lightrag-launcher.sh.
  2. Make it runnable: Open Terminal and run: 
    chmod +x ~/LightRAG/lightrag-launcher.sh

Next: 4. Creating the App

docs.title: 4. Creating the Mac App
docs.text: We will use Platypus to wrap the terminal script into a double-clickable Mac app.

docs.title: 1. Test the Script First
docs.text:
Before making the app, make sure your config works:

  1. Open Terminal and run: ~/LightRAG/lightrag-launcher.sh
  2. Wait until you see Uvicorn running on http://127.0.0.1:8020
  3. Go to http://127.0.0.1:8020 in your browser to verify it loads.
  4. Press Ctrl + C in Terminal to stop the server.

docs.title: 2. Create the App with Platypus
docs.text:
1. Open Platypus from your Applications folder.
  2. Fill out the settings exactly like this:
  3. App Name: LightRAG Server
  4. Script Path: Click "Select...", press ⇧ + ⌘ + G, type ~/LightRAG, and select lightrag-launcher.sh.
  5. Interface: Change to Text Window.
  6. Identifier: com.lightrag.server.app
  7. At the very bottom, make sure Run script in background and Remain running after script exits are both UNCHECKED.
  8. Click Create App at the bottom.
  9. Save it into your Applications folder.

You now have a clickable LightRAG Server.app in your Applications folder!

Next: 5. Usage Guide

docs.title: Start and Stop the Server
docs.text:
• Start: Open your Applications folder in Finder and double-click LightRAG Server.app.
  • Stop: Click the app's text window and press ⌘ + Q.

docs.title: Use the Web Interface
docs.text: When the app is running, go to: - Chat Interface: http://127.0.0.1:8020

docs.title: Add Documents
docs.text:
1. Open Finder and go to your home folder.
  2. Open LightRAG, then open inputs.
  3. Drag and drop PDF or TXT files into this inputs folder.
  4. Go to http://127.0.0.1:8020 and use the "Index" button to process the new files.

docs.title: Change Settings
docs.text:
1. Go to the LightRAG folder in Finder. (Press ⇧ + ⌘ + . if you don't see .env).
  2. Open .env in Zed.
  3. Make your changes (like switching the API key) and save.
  4. Restart the LightRAG Server.app to apply the changes.

Next: 6. Troubleshooting

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
App Quits Immediately 1. Open Terminal and run: ~/LightRAG/lightrag-launcher.sh to see the error. 2. If it says command not found, reinstall the tool: 

uv tool install "lightrag-hku[offline,observability]"
3. If it says Address already in use, open ~/LightRAG/.env in Zed and change PORT=8020 to PORT=8030.

Can't see .env in Finder Files starting with a dot are hidden by default. Open the LightRAG folder in Finder and press ⇧ + ⌘ + . to show them.

Server running but browser won't connect Check the app's text window to see exactly what port it started on, and ensure your browser matches (e.g., http://127.0.0.1:8020).

docs.title: File Locations
docs.text:
• The App: /Applications/LightRAG Server.app
  • Settings: ~/LightRAG/.env
  • Data & DB: ~/LightRAG/
  • Documents: ~/LightRAG/inputs/
  • Script: ~/LightRAG/lightrag-launcher.sh

docs.title: 1. What is LiteLLM?
docs.text:
LiteLLM is a proxy server. It lets your applications use one standard format (the OpenAI format) to talk to different AI providers (like Claude, Gemini, or local Ollama models) without changing any code.

Next: 2. Installation

docs.title: 2. Installation
docs.text:
Install LiteLLM using uv. Open Terminal and run:

uv tool install "litellm[proxy]"

To confirm it installed correctly, run:

litellm --version
(You should see a version number output).

Next: 3. Configuration

docs.title: 3. Configuration
docs.text: LiteLLM looks for a config.yaml file to know which models to serve and what API keys to use.

docs.title: 1. Create the Config File
docs.text:
1. Open Finder and go to your home folder (⇧ + ⌘ + H).
  2. Important: Press ⇧ + ⌘ + . to show hidden files. Finder will not let you create a folder starting with a dot unless hidden files are visible.
  3. Create a new folder (⇧ + ⌘ + N) and name it .litellm (it will warn you about starting with a dot, confirm it).
  4. Inside the .litellm folder, open Zed and create a new blank document.
  5. Paste the configuration block (see below) into the document.
  6. Save the document inside .litellm and name it EXACTLY config.yaml.

docs.title: 2. Config Template
docs.text:
This template sets up a cloud model (Gemini), a local model (Ollama), local/cloud embedding models (Nomic, Gemini), and a custom OpenAI-Compatible server. Copy and paste this into your config.yaml:

# ~/.litellm/config.yaml

litellm_settings:
  drop_params: True

model_list:
  # A local model using Ollama (Wildcard route for ANY Ollama model)
  - model_name: ollama/*
    litellm_params:
      model: ollama/*
      api_base: "http://localhost:11434" 

  # A local embedding model using Ollama
  - model_name: nomic-embed-text
    litellm_params:
      model: ollama/nomic-embed-text
      api_base: "http://localhost:11434"

  # A cloud embedding model using Gemini
  - model_name: gemini-embedding-001
    litellm_params:
      model: gemini/gemini-embedding-001
      api_key: "os.environ/GEMINI_API_KEY"

  # A cloud model using Gemini (Wildcard route for ANY Gemini model)
  - model_name: gemini/*
    litellm_params:
      model: gemini/*
      api_key: "os.environ/GEMINI_API_KEY"

  # An OpenAI-Compatible Server (e.g., vLLM, LM Studio, Together AI)
  - model_name: custom-openai-server
    litellm_params:
      model: openai/<your-model-name>
      api_base: "http://your-server-address/v1"
      api_key: "os.environ/CUSTOM_API_KEY" # Optional, if your server requires it

docs.title: How API Keys Work
docs.text:
The config uses os.environ/... to securely load API keys from your environment. You tell your Mac the key before starting the server.

Next: 4. Running the Server

docs.title: 1. Set API Keys
docs.text:
If you are using cloud providers, tell Terminal your API keys before starting the server. Open Terminal and run:

export GEMINI_API_KEY="AI..."
export CUSTOM_API_KEY="sk-..." # Only if your custom server requires it

Note: These only last until you close the window. (You can add those lines to your ~/.zshrc file if you want them to be permanent).

docs.title: 2. Start the Server
docs.text:
In the same Terminal window, start the server and point it to the config file:

litellm --config ~/.litellm/config.yaml

When you see Uvicorn running on http://0.0.0.0:4000, the server is ready. To stop it, press Ctrl + C.

Next: 5. Usage and Testing

docs.title: Test with curl
docs.text:
To test your server, keep it running in one Terminal tab, open a new Terminal tab (⌘ + T), and run:

curl http://localhost:4000/v1/chat/completions \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "model": "gemini/gemini-2.5-flash",
    "messages": [
      {
        "role": "user",
        "content": "Hey, how are you?"
      }
    ]
  }'
You should see a JSON response from the model. (Note: To test a local Ollama model instead, change "model": "gemini/gemini-2.5-flash" to "model": "ollama/mistral-nemo" or any other downloaded Ollama model).

docs.title: Test Embeddings
docs.text:
You can also test the local nomic-embed-text model:

curl http://localhost:4000/v1/embeddings \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "model": "gemini-embedding-001",
    "input": ["Hello world"]
  }'
(Note: To test your local Ollama embeddings instead, change "model": "gemini-embedding-001" to "model": "nomic-embed-text").

docs.title: Connect LightRAG to LiteLLM
docs.text:
To use LiteLLM as the engine for your LightRAG server, update your LightRAG/.env file in Zed:

LLM_BINDING=openai
LLM_BINDING_HOST=http://localhost:4000/v1
LLM_MODEL=gemini/gemini-2.5-flash 
LLM_BINDING_API_KEY=any-string-will-work
EMBEDDING_BINDING=openai
EMBEDDING_BINDING_HOST=http://localhost:4000/v1
EMBEDDING_MODEL=gemini-embedding-001

This tells LightRAG to send all generation and embedding requests to LiteLLM.

docs.title: 1. Initial Setup
docs.text: These are the notes for setting up this documentation site from scratch on a Mac.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
You need two things installed on your Mac. Open the Terminal app (⌘ + Space, type Terminal) and run these two commands one after the other:

  1. Homebrew: 
    /bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"
  2. uv:

docs.title: Setup the Project
docs.text:
1. Create the Folders (in Finder): Open Finder and go to your home folder (⇧ + ⌘ + H). Create a new folder named RAGprojects. Open that folder, and create another new folder inside it named rag-notes.

  2. Install MkDocs (in Terminal): In your new rag-notes folder in Finder, look at the very top menu bar and click View > Show Path Bar (or press ⌥ + ⌘ + P). You will see the folder path at the bottom of the Finder window. Right-click the rag-notes folder in that path and select Open in Terminal.

In the Terminal window that pops up, copy and paste this whole block: 

uv init --no-package
uv add mkdocs mkdocs-material
uv run mkdocs new .

  1. Configure the Site: Go back to the rag-notes folder in Finder. You will see a file named mkdocs.yml that was just created. Double-click mkdocs.yml to open it in Zed. Delete everything in the file, and paste this simple configuration instead:

site_name: My Notes
theme: material
nav:
  - Home: index.md
Save the file and close Zed.

docs.title: Run the Site
docs.text:
Whenever you want to view your notes locally on your Mac: 1. Open the rag-notes folder in Finder. 2. In the Path Bar at the bottom of the Finder window, Right-click rag-notes and select Open in Terminal. 3. Run the included script:

bash run_dev.sh

Then open your browser and go to http://127.0.0.1:8000.

Next: 2. Writing Content

docs.title: 2. Writing Content
docs.text: All your notes are just written in plain text files inside the docs/ folder, using Markdown format.

docs.title: Add a New Page
docs.text:
1. Create a file (in Finder): Open the RAGprojects/rag-notes/docs folder in Finder. Open Zed, create a new blank document (⌘ + N), and save it into that docs folder. Name it something like my-new-note.md (make sure it ends in .md, not .txt).

  2. Write in Markdown: In your new file, write your notes. Use # for headers, * for italics, ** for bold, and - for bullet points. 

    # My Note
This is a **bold** word.
- Point 1
- Point 2

  3. Add to the Menu: For the page to show up on the website's sidebar, you have to attach it to the navigation menu. Open your mkdocs.yml file in Zed. Under nav:, add the exact name of your new file: 

    nav:
  - Home: index.md
  - My New Note: my-new-note.md

Save the files. If the run_dev.sh server is currently running, your browser will update automatically.

docs.title: Organize in Folders
docs.text:
If you want to group notes together into sections: 1. Open the docs/ folder in Finder. 2. Create a new folder inside it (e.g., name it tutorials). 3. Save your .md files into that new folder. 4. Open mkdocs.yml in Zed. List the folder name as a section, and indent the files underneath it: 

nav:
  - Home: index.md
  - Tutorials:
    - Guide 1: tutorials/guide-1.md
    - Guide 2: tutorials/guide-2.md

Next: 3. Publishing Site

docs.title: 3. Publishing Site
docs.text: You can back up your notes to GitHub and host them on GitHub Pages for free.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
• You need a GitHub account.
  • You need Git installed. (If you aren't sure, don't worry—the Mac will automatically prompt you to install it if you try to run a git command without it).
  • Install the GitHub CLI: Open Terminal and run brew install gh

docs.title: 1. Initial Upload
docs.text:
If you are uploading this project for the first time, you need to use Terminal to send the files to GitHub.

  1. Open your rag-notes folder in Finder.
  2. In the Path Bar at the bottom of the window, Right-click rag-notes and select Open in Terminal. (If you don't see the Path Bar, click View > Show Path Bar in the top menu).
  3. In the Terminal window that opens, run these commands one after the other:

git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"
gh repo create rag-notes --source=. --remote=origin --push --public
(Note: If gh asks you to log in, just follow the prompts to open your browser and authenticate).

docs.title: 2. Publish to GitHub Pages
docs.text:
Once everything is uploaded, tell MkDocs to build the site and deploy it. In the same Terminal window, run:

uv run mkdocs gh-deploy

Your site will be live in a few minutes at https://<YOUR-GITHUB-USERNAME>.github.io/rag-notes/.

docs.title: 3. How to Update Later
docs.text:
Whenever you add new notes or make changes in Finder, you need to save and re-publish your site:

  1. Open your rag-notes folder in Finder.
  2. In the Path Bar, Right-click rag-notes and select Open in Terminal.
  3. Run these commands:
git add .
git commit -m "update notes"
git push
uv run mkdocs gh-deploy
